"**Up the Ladder to the Roof** " is a 1970 hit single recorded by [The
Supremes](/wiki/The_Supremes "The Supremes") for the [Motown](/wiki/Motown
"Motown") label. It was the first Supremes single to feature new lead singer
[Jean Terrell](/wiki/Jean_Terrell "Jean Terrell") in place of [Diana
Ross](/wiki/Diana_Ross "Diana Ross"), who officially left the group for a solo
career two weeks before the recording of this song in January 1970. This song
also marks a number of other firsts: it is the first Supremes single since
"[The Happening](/wiki/The_Happening_\(song\) "The Happening \(song\)")" in
1967 to be released under the name "The Supremes" instead of "Diana Ross & the
Supremes", the first Supremes single solely produced by [Norman
Whitfield](/wiki/Norman_Whitfield "Norman Whitfield") associate [Frank
Wilson](/wiki/Frank_Wilson_\(musician\) "Frank Wilson \(musician\)"), and the
first Supremes single to make the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom
"United Kingdom") Top 10 since
"[Reflections](/wiki/Reflections_\(The_Supremes_song\) "Reflections \(The
Supremes song\)")" in 1967.

Frank Wilson wrote the music for the song, with lyrics written by an Italian-
American songwriter from [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City")
named Vincent DiMirco.

"Up the Ladder to the Roof" rose to number ten on the [_Billboard_ Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100") and number five on the soul
chart, in the spring of 1970.[1] Outside the US, The Supremes scored a #6
smash with the song in the UK and number eight in Canada.

##
Personnel[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Up_the_Ladder_to_the_Roof&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Personnel")]

  * Lead vocals by [Jean Terrell](/wiki/Jean_Terrell "Jean Terrell")
  * Background vocals by [Mary Wilson](/wiki/Mary_Wilson_\(singer\) "Mary Wilson \(singer\)"), [Cindy Birdsong](/wiki/Cindy_Birdsong "Cindy Birdsong") and Jean Terrell [2]
  * Additional vocals by [The Andantes](/wiki/The_Andantes "The Andantes")
  * Instrumentation by [The Funk Brothers](/wiki/The_Funk_Brothers "The Funk Brothers")
  * Arranged by [David Van De Pitte](/wiki/David_Van_De_Pitte "David Van De Pitte")
